content.webTitle: ANU to base admission on year 11 because of 'significant disruption' from coronavirus

fields.headline: ANU to base admission on year 11 because of 'significant disruption' from coronavirus
fields.bodyText: The Australian National University will offer admission to undergraduate programs in 2021 based on year 11 results, in recognition of the “significant disruption” to year 12 students’ studies because of Covid-19. The ANU chancellor, former foreign minister Julie Bishop, told Guardian Australia the move recognised “the disruption across the country and the differing responses that schools and education systems have been forced to make”. Bishop also revealed the university was likely to miss out on the federal government’s jobkeeper wage subsidy program, as its revenue exceeds $1bn and it would “probably” suffer a decline in its turnover of 40%, short of the 50% threshold to qualify. Universities Australia, which is lobbying the education minister, Dan Tehan, for a separate support package, conservatively estimates that the sector will lose between $3bn and $4.6bn. On Wednesday University of Sydney revealed to its staff it was expecting to lose $470m this year. On Tuesday education ministers unanimously ruled out a “year 13” for students currently in year 12 to complete their studies in 2021. It is now up to each state and territory how to modify the end-of-year assessments in their jurisdiction, while the commonwealth will work with the university and vocational education sectors to determine how Australian tertiary admission ranks (Atar) will be assessed. The national cabinet has relied on expert medical advice to resist a push to close schools, but most high school education has shifted online, with most states and territories moving school holidays or using pupil-free days to prepare for terms two and three being delivered through e-learning after the Easter break. Under the ANU plan, current year 12 students will be allowed to apply between April and 25 May, with a round of offers to be made in August. Bishop said about 3,000-3,500 offers would be made based on year 11 results – with no conditions except that the student finish year 12. “This will give those wanting to study at ANU next year certainty and hopefully remove much of the stress and anxiety that they are likely to experience undertaking year 12 studies this year, with all the disruption and challenges coronavirus has wreaked upon our education systems,” she said. Bishop noted “the separate education systems across our states and territories are yet to determine how year 12 results and Atar will look”. “It’s hard to tell what year 12 will look like state to state. I don’t think there are many easy options for federal, state or territory governments and it’s going to be many months before we can judge the effectiveness of the approach we’ve taken so far. “So we want to make an offer now, knowing year 12 students will experience a tough year in 2020.” The ANU will later make a separate round of offers to students who rely on their year 12 Atar. Bishop said ANU had a “robust balance sheet” and was seeking to mitigate losses and prepare for various contingencies, and she hoped to keep as many staff as possible in jobs. On Tuesday the federal government made clear that universities – unlike charities – would still need to meet the threshold of 30% revenue reduction for organisations earning $1bn or less, and 50% for those above that threshold, to qualify for the jobkeeper scheme. Bishop said she was not in a position to say whether ANU would qualify for the $1,500 fortnightly wage subsidy for staff that have been stood down. “We might fall between – we’re over $1bn, but we’re probably about 40% [revenue decline].” On Wednesday Tehan confirmed the government was looking at other measures to help the university sector, and would have more to say in the next few days. “We think there will probably be increased demand next year for university, so we are working with them to make sure that we can provide the foundations that they’ll need to continue to be able to educate our children,” Tehan said.
